metadata.title: Articular Cartilage Defects of the Knee -Comorbid diagnoses:  Are there coexisting orthopedic problems or chronic health disorders, such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease, dementia, psychiatric disorders, or neuromuscular dysfunction? -Medications prescribed:  Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs) -Other symptoms:  Ask patient if there are symptoms other than knee pain (low back, groin, or hip)    •Social/occupational history –Patient’s goals:  Document the specific and general goals the patient hopes to accomplish with therapy (these are usually related to the frequency and severity of activity-related  knee pain during work or recreation) –Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any:  Does knee pain occur during participation in occupational or daily activities? Does patient participate in high-risk  activities that involve knee extension and pivoting (e.g., contact sports, agility running, swimming breaststroke; i.e., “whip-kick”)? –Functional limitations:  Does knee pain interfere with ADLs or use of adaptive equipment? –Living environment:  Are there barriers in the home that restrict access, such as stairs; any modifications necessary?
synonyms: cartilage defects, articular of the knee
articular cartilage lesions of the knee
hyaline cartilage tears of the knee
anatomical location body part affected: Knee joint or patellofemoral joint/hyaline cartilage of the medial and/or lateral femoral condyle, femoral trochlea, patella, tibial articular cartilage
description: In the absence of osteochondral disease, knee joint articular cartilage defects (ACDs) are mainly trauma-related  injuries to hyaline cartilage, in contrast to “wear-and-tear” osteoarthritis lesions(9)

Symptoms include knee pain, swelling, and mobility impairments. These symptoms are often unresponsive to conservative management because of the poor healing capacity of hyaline cartilage, especially when ACDs are large(2)
Surgical intervention is often favored due to concern for joint damage and the early onset of osteoarthritis without effective treatment, particularly in children and adolescents(2,9)
Four methods of operative care are arthroscopic lavage and debridement, microfracture, autologous chondrocyte implantation (ACI), and osteochondral autograft transplantation (OAT)(9)

ICD-10 codes.S83.3: tear of articular cartilage of knee (current)
ICD-10 codes.M93.2: osteochondritis dissecans (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: History of acute trauma to knee with hemarthrosis, or gradual onset of pain associated with repetitive trauma
Activity-related  pain; possibly restricts some physical activities (climbing stairs, squatting, hopping, or running)
Episodes of catching or locking (suggestive of loose bodies) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: In pediatric cases, obtain parental or guardian consent to perform the examination
Concomitant knee joint pathology (e.g., meniscal and ligament injuries) requires additional precautions during the exam
Patient unable to comprehend procedure because of language skills or cognitive impairment
Unresolved acute knee injury, inflammation, or infection

causes ,: Direct major trauma involving a shearing force to the knee, as might occur in sports,falls, accidents, or work injuries
pathogenesis: Current opinion is that ACDs heal poorly even with medical therapy, increasing in size and depth and worseningsymptomatically over time(9)
The Outerbridge classification system, which is used to classify grades of ACDs, is considered an outdatedsystem;researchers recommend incorporating MRI for appropriate diagnosis(10)

ACDs found on arthroscopy are most commonly located on the medial femoral condyle and the patellar facets and areassociated in a high percentage of cases with medial meniscus tears (37%) or anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) ruptures(36%)(9)
Without surgical intervention, full-thickness  ACDs undergo degenerative changes that might progress to osteoarthritis
The microfracture procedure is the most popular ACD repair technique and the gold standard against which othertechniques are compared(9)
ACI is used to treat articular cartilage lesions and has been shown to improve the outcomes of the knee. It is indicated forthose with symptomatic focal chondral and osteochondral defects(11)
Localizations of cartilage lesions generally occur along the medial femoral condyle and the articular surfaces of thepatella(9)

In surgical research studies, outcomes have been evaluated by clinical evaluation, MRI and CT imaging, “second-look”arthroscopy, histological examination of cartilage biopsy samples, and measurement of cartilage mechanical properties (9)
risk factors: Increased biomechanical stress on the knee joint due to lower extremity malalignment resulting from(2)–Medial meniscus tear(9)–ACL rupture(9)–Posterior root tears(9)–Partial meniscectomy–Sports injuries(9)–Delayed ACL reconstruction(9)–High BMI in young adult males(9)

overall contraindications precautions: Rule out fracture and test neurovascular status in patients with recent knee trauma with visible skin injury and inability to bear weight(2)
Significant neurological deficits are not usually associated with this condition. Consult with physician regarding sensory or motor deficits found in the involved limb
Follow physician orders for restrictions on weight-bearing,  knee ROM, and exercise therapy
Patient education is required for strict adherence to postoperative guidelines, such as use of continuous passive motion (CPM) machine and weight-bearing  limitations
Restrict/modify exercises that increase joint pain and swelling
Avoid knee joint passive mobilization after surgery
Avoid use of ultrasound near growth plates in pediatric cases
Notify referring physician immediately on discovery of evidence suggestive of DVT or thrombophlebitis
Refer immediately to emergency care if evidence of ischemia or paralysis is present in the affected limb
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: In pediatric cases, obtain parental or guardian consent to perform the examination
Concomitant knee joint pathology (e.g., meniscal and ligament injuries) requires additional precautions during the exam
Patient unable to comprehend procedure because of language skills or cognitive impairment
Unresolved acute knee injury, inflammation, or infection

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Patients will usually be able to describe the circumstances of their sudden knee injury, as well as the symptoms that followed

course of treatment.medical management: Conservative treatment usually consists of physical therapy, activity modification, and patient education. Has a knee brace/sleeve been prescribed for this condition? Patients are usually permitted to bear weight as tolerated and ambulate with axillary crutches. Postoperative rehabilitation involves early mobilization (straightleg raises, heel slides, prone leg hang, passive knee ROM)(9) Authors of a systematic review found that osteochondral allografts (OCA) transplantation had good functional outcomes,with a survival rate of 78.7%(5)
course of treatment.medications: Pain and swelling are usually treated with common analgesic medications such as oral NSAIDs. Document the medications prescribed and the patient’s opinion on their effectiveness
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Ask about results of X-rays  or other imaging studies. MRI or CT scans are used to
investigate for possible osteochondral damage and softtissue  derangement
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Has patient received acupuncture or tried taping/bracing knee or using ice or heat for pain/swelling?
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other related conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Patients usually experience increased discomfort/apprehension with general physical activity
history of present illness.body chart: If areas other than the knee are involved, use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Note whether any of the following symptoms are reported -Crepitation -Instability and giving-way -Locking (suggestive of loose bodies) -Stiffness -Other lower extremity pain
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment. Specifically address if pain is a common symptom and whether it is present now and how much
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document whether there are changes in symptoms throughout the day and night (i.e., A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to knee symptoms
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that might exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could indicate need for physician consultation, such as falling because of pain Barriers to learning -Is patient communication/education limited by cognitive impairment?

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Are there coexisting orthopedic problems or chronic health disorders, such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease, dementia, psychiatric disorders, or neuromuscular dysfunction?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient if there are symptoms other than knee pain (low back, groin, or hip)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does knee pain occur during participation in occupational or daily activities? Does patient participate in high-risk  activities that involve knee extension and pivoting (e.g., contact sports, agility running, swimming breaststroke; i.e., “whip-kick”)?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does knee pain interfere with ADLs or use of adaptive equipment?
social and occupational history.living environment: Are there barriers in the home that restrict access, such as stairs; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate ›Relevant tests and measures:  (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, weight-bearing  status, and stage of healing)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate need for assistive ambulatory device (cane, crutches, rarely a walker) and modify prescription, as appropriate. Assess fit and safe operation of immobilizer brace or assistive devices. Assess ability to correctly don/doff knee brace, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess stability and for nonsymmetrical weight-bearing  in standing. If not full weight-bearing  status, assess stability in standing using assistive device. Prior to discharge, assess balance in 1-leg  stand with perturbations. Use objective measures such as the Star Excursion Balance test or Berg Balance test
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses should be intactAssess for knee swelling and thigh atrophy with circumference measurements
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Inspect lower extremity movement in walking on treadmill. Compare sides. Examine for activity limitations and participation restrictions using simple performance tests (e.g., 6-minute  walk for distance test [6MWT], single-leg  hop, Timed Up and Go [TUG] test)(9)Assess passive mobility and dynamic tracking of the patella. If not in acute stage, assess for injury to knee ligaments and menisci. Compare to unaffected knee. Use caution when assessing joint accessory motion
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of the gluteals and entire lower extremity. Compare quadriceps-hamstrings  strength ratio to contralateral side. When weight-bearing  status permits, assess ability to perform half-squat  with affected leg
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess: -Vastus medialis oblique (VMO) for atrophy, tone, and activation at terminal knee extension -Lateral and medial retinaculum for tightness and tenderness -Patellofemoral joint for crepitation. Patellar ACDs are very common(9)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess knee alignment for genu varum or valgus
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active and passive ROM at knee joint with goniometerAchilles and patellar tendon reflexes should be intact
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensation should be intact except for localized deficits around surgical wounds, if applicable. Assess knee proprioception

contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide and does not replace orders from a physician or the specific protocols of the treatment clinic
Cryotherapy contraindications(1) -Raynaud’s syndrome -Cryoglobulinemia -Cold urticaria -Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria -Impaired circulation -Over area of nerve regrowth
Cryotherapy precautions(1) -Hypertension -Hypersensitivity to cold -Over an acute wound -Over superficial nerves

Aquatic therapy  contraindications/precautions(1) -Fear of water -Avoid warm/hot water if patient is pregnant or has multiple sclerosis, increased risk of hemorrhage (e.g., on anticoagulant medications), impaired thermal regulation, acute inflammation, fever, edema, thrombophlebitis, or acute rheumatoid arthritis -Epilepsy -Cardiovascular or pulmonary disease -Open wounds, catheters, colostomies, IVs, G-tubes -Urinary or fecal incontinence -Certain dermatologic conditions (e.g., ichthyosis, infection) -Venous ulcers -Tissues damaged by radiation therapy -Peripheral vascular disease -Respiratory impairment -More than half-body  immersion during pregnancy

Thermotherapy contraindications(1) -Decreased circulation -Decreased sensation -Acute/subacute traumatic and inflammatory conditions -Skin infections -Impaired cognition or language barrier -Tumors -Liniments -Tendency for hemorrhage or edema -Heat rubs

Whirlpool contraindications  (1) -Certain dermatologic conditions (e.g., ichthyosis, infection) -Venous ulcers -Tissues damaged by radiation therapy -Peripheral vascular disease -Respiratory impairment -Surgical incisions/skin grafts -Malignancy -More than half-body  immersion during pregnancy

Whirlpool precautions (*some are relevant only if more than one limb is immersed)(1) -Cardiac insufficiency -Impaired sensation -Impaired mental status -Unstable blood pressure  -Cold hypersensitivity -Alcohol consumption (prior to therapy)* -Decreased strength/ROM/endurance/balance* -Urinary/fecal incontinence* -Fear of water* -Respiratory impairments -Avoid warm/hot water if patient is pregnant, or has multiple sclerosis, increased risk of hemorrhage (e.g., on anticoagulant medications), impaired thermal regulation, acute inflammation, fever, edema, thrombophlebitis, or acute rheumatoid arthritis -Seasickness -Epilepsy*

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions(1) -Do not place electrodes near: -carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads -Osteomyelitis -Hemorrhage -Impaired sensation, mental status, communication -Cardiovascular disease -Malignancy -Dermatological conditions -Proximity of electromagnetic radiation -In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen -In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck -History of spontaneous abortion in pregnant women

Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications; do not use:(1) -over the region of a cardiac pacemaker -over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy -over the eyes or testes -in an area with infection or bleeding -if a tumor or malignancy is present in the area -in the area of a DVT or thrombophlebitis -over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia -over epiphyseal plates

Therapeutic ultrasound precautions(1) -Sensory deficits -Ineffective communication skills in a patient (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier) -Circulatory impairments -Plastic or metal implants -Peripheral vascular disease -Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Inform patient and family/caregivers of the potential for falls and educate about fall-prevention strategies
Use a sterile field and sterile techniques when treating open lesions; dressings that retain moisture are contraindicated in the presence of infection
Allow for wound healing prior to functional rehabilitation

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Mechanical knee pain with limitations in general and recreational activities
assessment plan of care.rule out: Other recent knee procedures that might explain symptoms;e.g., collateral ligament/cruciate ligament tear; meniscal injury; osteoarthritis; chondromalacia patella; osteochondritis dissecans; popliteal cyst; pre-patellar  bursitis
prognosis: Patients who have received microfracture treatment ACI are likely to experience good clinical outcomes based on the LysholmKnee Scoring Scale and Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS) outcome scores(7)

Authors of an RCT (28 men, 12 women; ages 18–50  years) investigating outcomes 15–17  years after mosaicplasty (a type of OAT) or microfracture in Norway found that Lysholm scores were significantly higher in the mosaicplasty group (average Lysholm score of 77 versus 61) in the microfracture group(3)

Authors of an RCT (N = 37 knees [in 35 patients] treated with matrix-induced  autologous chondrocyte implantation) in Australia found at 2 years follow-up  that the MRI composite infill scores were good to excellent in 100% of the group  that returned to full weightbearing (FWB) 6 weeks postoperatively, compared to 83% in the group that returned to FWB 8 weeks postoperatively(4)
Patients with untreated focal chondral defects are more likely to experience cartilage damage leading to osteoarthritis, resulting in more pain and dysfunction(6)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Orthopedic physician for specific red flags and persisting inability to achieve full ROM; aquatic therapist for pool exercise
treatment summary: Delay return to regular activities, depending on type of surgery
Progressive gluteal and lower extremity strengthening with neuromuscular electric stimulation, depending on type of surgery

Surgical rehabilitation protocol has been established for an osteochondral allograft transplantation(8) –Phase I (0–6 weeks) -Begin early ROM exercises to minimize contractures and intraarticular scarring -Weight bearing is limited to heel touch -An extension brace will likely be incorporated. The knee should be locked in full extension except when performing strengthening exercises or when using a CPM device -CPM should be utilized for at least 6 hours a day starting at 0–40  degrees range and advancing 5–10 degrees per day as patient tolerates -Exercises performed should include quadriceps sets, straight leg raises, calf-pumps,  and passive leg hangs to 90 degrees –Phase II (6–8 weeks) -Weight bearing should start at 25% of the patient’s body weight and progress 25% weekly until FWB -ROM should continue to increase with use of the CPM device and PROM exercises; goal should be to achieve 130 degrees of knee flexion -Exercises should focus on continued strengthening, flexibility, cardiovascular training, and neuromuscular control -Manual therapy such as scar tissue management and patellar mobilization can be performed –Phase III (8–12  weeks) -Progress to full and pain-free  active and passive ROM -Gait training should be performed with weight bearing as tolerated -Closed-chain  exercises can be initiated –Phase IV (12 weeks–6  months) -Normal ADLs should be incorporated -Neuromuscular dynamic stability exercises should focus on single-limb  exercises -Advanced strengthening exercises can be performed as tolerated -By this phase, patients should be able to achieve quadriceps and hamstring strengthening within 10% of the contralateral leg before progressing to phase V –Phase V (6–12  months) -Sport-specific  exercises can be performed -Athletes may progress to more explosive and high-demand  activities such as plyometrics . Problem Goal Intervention Expected ProgressionHome Exercise Program  Pain _ _ EffusionDecrease pain/ tenderness _ _ Reduce edemaPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Cryotherapy for pain and edema. Heat, whirlpool, and contrast baths to relieve stiffness _ _ Joint protection _ Restrict weight-bearing according to physician instructions. Although casting, bracing, or an immobilizer might be prescribed for joint protection, avoid the adverse effects of prolonged immobilizationN/A Recommend strategies for the home to assist in relieving pain/effusion as appropriate and indicated for each

physician clearance for return to regula: Activity limitation measures; e.g., 6MWT, 1-leg  hop test, TUG test
Knee Outcome Survey – Activities of Daily Living Scale
improved balance: Berg Balance test, Star Excursion Balance test

maintenance or prevention: Continue quadriceps strengthening to restore symmetry
Avoid participating in deep squatting activities with weights secondary to compressive forces on knee
Continue gluteal and lower extremity training to improve patellar control
patient education: Boston Children’s Hospital website, “Articular Cartilage Injury,” http://www.childrenshospital.org/conditions-and-treatments/conditions/a/articular-cartilage-injury/overview Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
